comment.author: 46696233@N00
comment._content: Charles 'The Little Apache" Ledoux (but he was French. Those were weird times) www.boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=17961&cat=boxer won 99 (KO 81) + lost 29 (KO 3) + drawn 6

comment.author: 8623220@N02

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Not a hotel room -- this was a gym where boxers trained. A November 24, 1913, photo of boxer Charles Morris shows another chamber in this suite, with the identical wallpaper: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4605956627/] @undeadsinatra: In the 19th century, a cult of the Apache was active in the French underworld, especially in Paris. They took their name from the Apache Indians of North America, and were famous for their costumes, wearing flashy shirts with horizontal stripes. Here is an explanation on Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_(gang) Ledoux probably got his nickname because he was French (and a fierce fighter).

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Here's a Bain/LOC photo of boxer Bob Diry, training in the same gym, with the same weird wallpaper:

comment.author: 8560391@N03
comment._content: Charles Ledoux was a gritty, hard-hitting French bantamweight who mixed it up with many of the best fighters in his weight range during a long boxing career (1909-1925)—such greats as Joe Bowker, Johnny Buff, Joe Burman, Eddie Campi, Johnny Curtin, Kid Francis, Danny Kramer, Andre Routis, Sid Smith, Digger Stanley, and Hall of Famers Johnny Coulon, Eugene Criqui, Jim Driscoll, Joe Lynch, Kid Williams and the legendary Pete Herman. He was at one time recognized by London's National Sporting Club as the world bantamweight champion (Coulon had wider recognition). In 1913, at the age of 20, Ledoux lost a decision to Campi for the vacant bantamweight title of the old IBU and less than a month later he was beaten by Williams, who claimed the world title; Williams would go on to beat Campi and Coulon as well to cement his claim. Ledoux would have to wait a long time for another shot at the bantamweight title. At the age of 32 and nearing the end of his years in the ring, Ledoux challenged world champion Abe Goldstein and lost a 15-round decision. Less than a year later he hung up his gloves for good. Ledoux died in 1967 at the age of 74.
